overview: This subject examines the major intensive animal production systems in Australia and internationally, with a focus on the impact of management practices on the health and welfare of animal populations.  Through industry-based placements as well as case-based syndicate work relevant to the major intensive production systems (poultry, pigs, fish and laboratory animals), students will develop an appreciation of the major determinants of profitability, productivity and sustainability of these industries, be able to describe the basic principles of breeding, management, nutrition, animal welfare and disease control as they relate to intensive animal production systems, and be able to specify where veterinary input may be important. Students will gain an understanding of the ethical and legal frameworks that govern the major intensive livestock industries in Australia, assuring the safe, ethical and legal production of food products.

additional pre-requisite: Permission of the Faculty of Science is required to enrol into this subject. Enrolment is limited to BSc students who have been selected into the Veterinary Bioscience major, leading to articulation into the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine.

assessments.description: Up to five online assessments (each equally weighted). 1000 words (equivalent)

1 Week extramural placement. 5 days (placement). Hurdle requirement:. The successful completion of a one-week extramural placement is a hurdle requirement for this subject. Approved placements may be local, regional, interstate, international or virtual.
assessments.timing: to be completed by the end of semester 2, in non-teaching periods

assessments.description: Written summary. 500 words. Hurdle requirement:. Students must satisfactorily complete a 500 word written summary of the placement.

Semester 2.Coordinators: Vern Bowles and Andres Diaz Mendez

Semester 2.Contact hours:
100 hours of lectures, case studies and practical classes
+ 1 week (35 hours) of extramural placement undertaken in non-teaching periods

Prescribed texts: There are no specifically prescribed or recommended texts for this subject.
